FacilityName: Helena Chemical Company - Garden City, KS Facility

_prev_prog_3.MH_OtherType: Vehicle or Projectile Strike, Vandalism, Theft, or Terrorism
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Storage tank, process piping, valves, transfer hoses, pumps, blenders, etc...
_prev_prog_3.Description:
The Helena Chemical Company (HCC) Garden City Facility Fertilizer Manager implements the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) and combined Risk Management Plan (RMP) Program (PSM/RMPr) for the OSHA and RMP covered process at this Facility and is assisted by other trained HCC staff as directed. The PSM/RMPr includes all Program 3 Accident Prevention Program elements: Management System, Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractor, Pre-Startup Review, Mechanical Integrity, Hot Work Permit, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Emergency Response, and Compliance Audits. 



Anhydrous ammonia is transferred from a commercial tanker truck into the single 30,000-gallon stationary storage tank by the commercial tanker truck operator, and in accordance with the Anhydrous Ammonia Operating Procedures.  The Contractor/Vendor is responsible for complying with its internal and relevant operations, maintenance, training, and contingency procedures as related to the commercial tanker truck operations.  The Facility is responsible for operating and maintaining this covered process in accordance with its Accident Prevention Program.

_prev_prog_3.MH_OtherType: Vehicle or Projectile Strike, Vandalism, Theft, or Terrorism
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Process piping, valves, transfer hoses, pumps, air compressor, and mix pots
_prev_prog_3.Description:
The Helena Chemical Company (HCC) Garden City Facility Fertilizer Manager implements the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) and combined Risk Management Plan (RMP) Program (PSM/RMPr) for the OSHA and RMP covered process at this Facility and is assisted by other trained HCC staff as directed. The PSM/RMPr includes all Program 3 Accident Prevention Program elements: Management System, Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractor, Pre-Startup Review, Mechanical Integrity, Hot Work Permit, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Emergency Response, and Compliance Audits. 



Base (i.e. 10-30-0) is a fertilizer that is manufactured by blending water, mono-ammonium phosphate (MAP), and clay suspension (a gelling agent).  Once the anhydrous ammonia is blended, the anhydrous ammonia becomes inert and therefore the Base product is not subject to the PSM/RMP.  The Base Blending Process equipment is owned by the Facility and is operated by trained Process Operators.  The Base Blending Process does not have any storage capabilities for anhydrous ammonia but it is physically connected to Covered Process 1 by process piping.  Facility Process Operators transfer the anhydrous ammonia from Covered Process 1 to one of the two (2) Mix Pots in the Base Blending Process in accordance with the Base Blending Process Operating Procedures.  Once blended, the Base product is transferred directly to commercial tanker trucks for delivery to the client.  The Facility is responsible for operating and maintaining this covered process in accordance with its Accident Prevention Program.

_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Pumps, process piping, flanges, transfer hoses, valving, and safety systems/valves.
_prev_prog_3.Description:
The Helena Chemical Company (HCC) Garden City Facility Fertilizer Manager implements the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) and combined Risk Management Plan (RMP) Program (PSM/RMPr) for the OSHA and RMP covered process at this Facility and is assisted by other trained HCC staff as directed. The PSM/RMPr includes all Program 3 Accident Prevention Program elements: Management System, Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractor, Pre-Startup Review, Mechanical Integrity, Hot Work Permit, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Emergency Response, and Compliance Audits. 



Ammonium Polyphosphate (i.e. 10-34-0) is a liquid fertilizer that is manufactured by blending anhydrous ammonia with water and super-phosphoric acid in a ?Mobile Pipe Reactor? (MPR).  The MPR process equipment is owned and operated by an Independent Fertilizer Reacting Contractor (IFRC).  The MPR does not have any storage capabilities for anhydrous ammonia.  Anhydrous ammonia is transferred from the single stationary storage tank by process piping to the MPR in accordance with the Mobile Fertilizer Reactor Operating Procedures.  Once the anhydrous ammonia is blended, the anhydrous ammonia becomes inert and therefore the ammonium polyphosphate product is not subject to the PSM/RMP.  The 10-34-0 is transferred into dedicated stationary storage tanks.  Trained Process Operators may provide oversight of the IFRC while they are making connections to the Facility equipment, but in general all facility personnel are trained to keep away from the Covered Process while it is operating.  The IFRC is responsible for operating and maintaining this covered process in accordance with its Accident Prevention Program as defined in the IFRC PSM.

_prev_prog_2.FR_OtherType: LaRoche Industries inc. - Aqua Ammonia Information Manual, 1997
_prev_prog_2.MH_OtherType: Vehicle or Projectile Strike, Vandalism, Theft, or Terrorism
_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: Storage tank, process piping, valves, pump, containment
_prev_prog_2.Description:
The Helena Chemical Company (HCC) Garden City Facility Fertilizer Manager implements the Risk Management Plan (RMP) and Risk Management Program (RMPr) for the storage and handling of aqueous ammonia at this facility, and is assisted by other Helena staff as directed. The RMPr includes all Program 2 Accident Prevention Program elements: Safety Information, Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Maintenance, Compliance Audits, Incident Investigation, and Emergency Response.  



Aqueous ammonia is transferred from a commercial tanker truck into the single 22,665-gallon stationary storage tank by the commercial tanker truck operator, and in accordance with the Aqueous Ammonia Operating Procedures.  The Contractor/Vendor is responsible for complying with its internal and relevant operations, maintenance, training, and contingency procedures as related to the commercial tanker truck operations.  HCC Process Operators are trained to (1) operate positioning of valves if needed, (2) monitor the level of aqueous ammonia in the storage tank, (3) maintain a presence at some distance from the covered process and oversee the transfer operation, and (4) be prepared to activate any valves to stop an uncontrolled flow of aqueous ammonia if required.  The Facility is responsible for operating and maintaining this covered process in accordance with its Accident Prevention Program.

_prev_prog_2.FR_OtherType: LaRoche Industries, Inc. - Aqua Ammonia Informational Manual, 1997
_prev_prog_2.MH_OtherType: Vehicle or Projectile Strike, Vandalism, Theft, or Terrorism
_prev_prog_2.PC_OtherType: air actuated valves at the blender
_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: Process piping, pump, valves, blender and mix pot, containment
_prev_prog_2.Description:
The Helena Chemical Company (HCC) Garden City Facility Fertilizer Manager implements the Risk Management Plan (RMP) and Risk Management Program (RMPr) for the transfer and blending of aqua ammonia at this facility, and is assisted by other Helena staff as directed.  The RMPr includes all Program 2 Accident Prevention Program elements: Safety Information, Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Maintenance, Compliance Audits, Incident Investigation, and Emergency Response.  



O-Phos is a fertilizer that is manufactured by blending aqueous ammonia with water and phosphoric acid in an Initial Blender (pipe blender), cooling tower, and heat exchanger.  The solution is then transferred to the O-Phos Mix Pot and blended with other confidential ingredients.  Once the aqueous ammonia is blended in the Initial Blender, the aqueous ammonia becomes inert and therefore the O-Phos product is not subject to the PSM/RMP.  The O-Phos Blending Process equipment is owned by the Facility and is operated by trained Process Operators.  The O-Phos Blending Process does not have any storage capabilities for aqueous ammonia but it is physically connected to Covered Process 4 by process piping.  Facility Process Operators transfer the aqueous ammonia from Covered Process 4 to the Initial Blender in accordance with the O-Phos Blending Process Operating Procedures.  Once blended, the O-Phos product is transferred to a storage tank.  The Facility is responsible for operating and maintaining this covered process in accordance with its Accident Prevention Program.

_emerg_resp.FR_OtherRegulation: This is a non-responding facility and it coordinates its response activities with the LEPC and local Fire Department.  Notification information and procedures are provided in its Contingency Plan.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



This Process Safety Management (PSM) and Risk Management Plan (RMP) Program document (PSM/RMPr) was prepared on behalf of Helena Chemical Company (HCC) pursuant to the requirements of the Clean Air Act ? 112(r) as codified by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) at 29 CFR ? 1910.119 and by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) at 40 CFR ?68.  The OSHA PSM and EPA Subpart D RMP standards are applicable to operations at the Garden City Facility, Garden City, KS.  At this Facility, HCC engages in the formulation, distribution and sale of chemicals (i.e. retail) to customers, most of who use HCC's products to support agricultural operations.  



This electronic submittal provides conservative estimates of the offsite consequences of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia and aqua ammonia from the Garden City Facility located at 1004 N. Anderson Road, Garden City, KS 67846.  The electronic RMP summarizes the policies and procedures implemented by the Garden City Facility to minimize the likelihood of an accident.  The electronic RMP also summarizes the actions that the Garden City Facility has taken to ensure that a response to a release (even though a release is unlikely) will be implemented in a proper and timely manner.



PURPOSE FOR UPDATING RMP



HCC is submitting this plan as a 5-year update.  All applicable sections of the EPA RMP Submit and the Facility Program 3 PSM/RMPr have been addressed.  



FACILITY



The Operations at the Garden City Facility consists of agricultural chemical storage and handling, manufacturing, retail sale and distribution.  As related to the PSM/RMPr, the Garden City Facility stores and handles two covered chemicals (anhydrous ammonia and aqua ammonia) at quantities that exceed the threshold quantity established by EPA, and operates five (5) covered processes that involve storage, handling, and processing of the covered chemicals.  The five covered processes include:



o    Covered

Process 1: Anhydrous Ammonia Storage & Handling

o    Covered Process 2: Base Blending Process

o    Covered Process 3: Mobile Fertilizer Reactor

o    Covered Process 4: Aqueous Ammonia Storage & Handling

o    Covered Process 5: O-Phos Blending Process



The Garden City Facility receives anhydrous ammonia and aqua ammonia by commercial tanker truck.  The commercial tanker truck is temporarily parked at the Facility until the covered chemicals are transferred from the commercial tanker truck to either Covered Process 1 (anhydrous) or 4 (aqueous).  Once the transfer is complete, the commercial tanker truck leaves the Facility.  



The anhydrous ammonia contained in Covered Process 1 (i.e. 30,000-gallon stationary pressure vessel) is used as an ingredient to make other types of fertilizers in Covered Processes 2 and 3.  Covered Process 2 is a stationary blender that is owned and operated by the Facility.  Covered Process 3 is a Mobile Pipe Reactor that is owned and operated by an Independent Fertilizer Reacting Contractor (IFRC).  Covered Processes 2 and 3 do not have any storage capacity to store anhydrous ammonia.  However, Covered Process 2 is physically connected to Covered Process 1 by process piping and Covered Process 3 is physically connected to Covered Process 1 by transfer hose when on-site and operating.  The fertilizer that is blended in Covered Process 2 is referred to as Base or 10-30-0.   Base (i.e. 10-30-0) is a fertilizer that is manufactured by blending water, mono-ammonium phosphate (MAP), and clay suspension (a gelling agent).  Once the anhydrous ammonia is blended, the anhydrous ammonia becomes inert and therefore the Base product is not subject to the PSM/RMP.  The fertilizer that is blended in Covered Process 3 is referred to as ammonium polyphosphate or 10-34-0.   Ammonium Polyphosphate (i.e. 10-34-0) is a liquid fertilizer that is manufactured by blending anhydrous ammonia with water and super-phosphoric acid in a "Mobile Pipe Reactor" (MPR).  Once th

e anhydrous ammonia is blended, the anhydrous ammonia becomes inert and therefore the ammonium polyphosphate product is not subject to the PSM/RMP.  



The aqueous ammonia contained in Covered Process 4 (i.e. 22,665-gallons aboveground storage tank) is used as an ingredient to make other types of fertilizers in the Covered Process 5.  Covered Process 5 is a stationary blender that is owned and operated by the Facility.  Covered Process 5 does not have any storage capacity to store aqueous ammonia.  However, Covered Process 5 is physically connected to Covered Process 4 by process piping.  The fertilizer that is blended in Covered Process 5 is referred to as O-Phos.  O-Phos is a fertilizer that is manufactured by blending aqueous ammonia with water and phosphoric acid in an Initial Blender (pipe blender), cooling tower, and heat exchanger.  The solution is then transferred to the O-Phos Mix Pot and blended with other confidential ingredients.  Once the aqueous ammonia is blended in the Initial Blender, the aqueous ammonia becomes inert and therefore the O-Phos product is not subject to the PSM/RMP.  



It is important to note that the total quantity of anhydrous ammonia that can be stored in Covered Process 1 is 184,948 lbs (assuming that the 30,000-gallon pressure vessel and a 9,600-gallon commercial tanker truck are filled to their administrative capacities); and the total aqua ammonia that can be stored in Covered Process 4 is 48,200 lbs (assuming that the 22,665-gallon AST and the 8,000-gallon commercial tanker truck are filled to their administrative capacities).  While Covered Processes 2, 3, and 5 are not able to store the respective covered chemical, they are considered a Covered Process per the rule.  As required by the EPA Database, covered processes must have quantities that are equal to or greater than the EPA threshold quantity.  For this reason, the total quantity reported in the EPA RMP Submit Report is greater than the total quantity that is actuall

y stored at the Facility.



OFF-SITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS



Worst case and alternative case consequence analyses were completed for all five (5) covered processes. The worst case scenario release assumed that all the contents in the largest single vessel were released.  For the anhydrous ammonia (i.e. representing Covered Processes 1, 2, and 3), the worst case release was modeled as if the 30,000-gallon anhydrous ammonia pressure vessel was punctured on the side at the ground level and the resulting release being a ground level horizontal jet at the maximum temperature.  For the aqua ammonia (i.e. representing Covered Processes 4 and 5), the worst case release scenario assumes that the 22,665-gallon aqua ammonia AST failed and instantaneously spills the content into secondary containment that has a total containment capacity of 12,492 gallons when considering displacement of the other ASTs within the containment.  Therefore, some of the aqueous ammonia spills over the containment and collects onto the ground.  For purposes of determining the impacted surface area adjacent to the containment, it was assumed that the aqueous ammonia covers the impacted areas to a depth of 1 cm.  The resulting release is evaporation at the maximum temperature.  



Depending on the covered process, the alternative (or more likely to occur) scenario for anhydrous ammonia assumes a release of anhydrous ammonia due to (1) rupture of a 3-inch transfer hose during a major loading or unloading operation associated with Covered Process 1; (2) leaking 2-inch process piping during transfer and blending at Covered Process 2; and rupture of a 3-inch transfer hose during transfer and blending at Covered Process 3.  Although these events are classified as an alternative scenario, even an accident of this type is unlikely to occur due to the safety equipment (i.e. excess flow devices, emergency shutoff valves, and internal safety valves on the commercial tanker truck; emergency shutoff valve at th

e pressure vessel; and emergency shutoff valves at the MPR) and operating procedures that HCC uses to safeguard ammonia transfer operations.



The alternative (or more likely to occur) scenario for Covered Process 4 assumes a release of aqua ammonia due to the rupture of a 2-inch transfer hose during a major loading or unloading operation and the alternative release scenario for Covered Process 5 is a leak in the process piping (i.e. between the AST and Initial Blender) that occurs during a transfer and blending operation.  Although these events are classified as an alternative scenario, an accident of this type is unlikely to occur due to the operating procedures that HCC uses to safeguard aqueous ammonia transfer operations.



ACCIDENT PREVENTION PROGRAM



The Garden City Fertilizer Manager implements the risk management planning process at this Facility.  The Garden City Fertilizer Manager is assisted by other trained HCC staff, as directed.  The Garden City Fertilizer Manager is responsible for ensuring that HCC Staff are properly trained in the implementation of the Program 2 and 3 Accident Prevention Program elements: Management System, Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractor, Pre-Startup Review, Mechanical Integrity, Hot Work Permit, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Emergency Response, and Compliance Audits.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



HCC's Garden City Facility is a non-responding facility. HCC has coordinated emergency response activities with its local emergency response agency and local fire department.



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



There have been no on-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage; or off-site deaths, injuries, property damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place, in the past five (5) years because of the ammonia operations at the Garden City Facility.



CONCLUSION



The Risk Management Plan implemented by HCC at the Garden

City Facility complies with the requirements of the Clean Air Act, Section 112(r).  The RMP will be updated as the Garden City Facility adds, deletes, or changes processes.  The Emergency Response Program has been coordinated with the Finney County LEPC and local Fire Department.



NOTE: Sections 4, 5, and 6 of EPA's RMP Submit Program are not applicable to the Garden City Facility.
